ticket.title: Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported
ticket.original-body: The fix in #288 is a serious security vulnerability and should be backported to all stable branches.
ticket.latest-body: The fix in #288 is a serious security vulnerability and should be backported to all stable branches.
ticket.original-body-html: The fix in #288 is a serious security vulnerability and should be backported to all stable branches.

version.body: The fix in #288 is a serious security vulnerability and should be backported to all stable branches.
version.body-html: The fix in #288 is a serious security vulnerability and should be backported to all stable branches.
version.title: Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported
Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported
Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported

version.body:
More info about the problem on this blog post: http://blog.innerewut.de/2008/6/16/why-you-should-upgrade-to-rails-2-1
The facts we have:
* The problem is fixed in the abstract adapter for 2.1.0 * The problem is *not* fixed for the 2.0 or 1.2 branches * The problem is *not* fixed for the mysql adapter for 2.1.0, but *will* be fixed when 2.1.1 is released. This is not such a huge issue as mysql stops more than one query being sent at once
So basically it's not a huge issue that the mysql adapter fix hasn't been released for the 2.1 branch, but no fix at all has been released for the other branches and so they are both vulnerable.
version.body-html:
More info about the problem on this blog post: http://blog.innerewut.de/2008/6/...

The facts we have:

  • The problem is fixed in the abstract adapter for 2.1.0
  • The problem is not fixed for the 2.0 or 1.2 branches
  • The problem is not fixed for the mysql adapter for 2.1.0, but will be fixed when 2.1.1 is released. This is not such a huge issue as mysql stops more than one query being sent at once

So basically it's not a huge issue that the mysql adapter fix hasn't been released for the 2.1 branch, but no fix at all has been released for the other branches and so they are both vulnerable.
version.title: Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported

version.body:
We surveyed folks a while back. Pretty much nobody is affected by this. I agree it's backport-worthy, but it's not a crisis.
Care to backport it?
version.body-html:
We surveyed folks a while back. Pretty much nobody is affected by this. I agree it's backport-worthy, but it's not a crisis.

Care to backport it?
version.title: Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported

version.body:
What's the criteria for a security issue being considered a "priority"? I run with postgres on the 2.0 branch, which means my application would be vulnerable if we were using user-specified offset/limit. Granted a very small number of people run postgres/sqlite compared to mysql, and presumably a smaller number still allow the user to specify limit/offset, but it seems this *could* affect somebody, and would be quite serious for them if they were targeted.
Anyway, I'd be happy to backport it, will report back with a patch.
version.body-html:
What's the criteria for a security issue being considered a "priority"? I run with postgres on the 2.0 branch, which means my application would be vulnerable if we were using user-specified offset/limit. Granted a very small number of people run postgres/sqlite compared to mysql, and presumably a smaller number still allow the user to specify limit/offset, but it seems this could affect somebody, and would be quite serious for them if they were targeted.

Anyway, I'd be happy to backport it, will report back with a patch.
version.title: Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported
Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported
Fix for SQL injection on :limit and :offset should be backported

version.body: jimmy choo replica is a brand that every woman is familiar with-maybe not through directly owning designer handbags of the coveted, thomas wylde bags-but through its countless cultural references. If you saw "The Devil Wears Prada", the episode of Family replica burberry where Meg saves up to buy replica burberry handbags, or were alive in the 90s-you have got to be familiar with this brand. In 1913 chloe handbags founded the now-famous Italian fashion house, beginning as a fine luxury goods store in Milan, Italy. Although dior replica took some time before the brand achieved cult like status-unlike many other famous brands such as replica louis vuitton, hermes replica and fendi handbags was worth the wait. This brand got its first nod from the high fashion world in the 1980s, with the release of the replica prada handbags. It was functional, stylish and fun-becoming an instant hit in the fashion world-an replica handbags inspiration for our quality, burberry handbags. The aesthetic of Prada (as well as our identical, cartier handbags is clean lines, traditional colors and a truly feminine aesthetic-something that set it apart in its high-fashion heyday. Part of its appeal is the "anti-snobbery," of the brand-the bottega veneta are understated, in traditional colors, with a very understated silver and valentino replica, bearing the name "Prada" in small lettering. This is quite unlike other high end replica fendi such as Louis Vuitton, Gucci and thomas wylde handbags monogram patterns are splattered on many of the bottega veneta replica in the collections. Prada achieved its ultimate, cult like status in prada replica in the 90s, when the replica balenciaga became a symbol of the successful working, versace bags symbol she could afford to buy for herself and flaunt her working status with. Whatever versace handbags youre looking to make with your replica cheap burberry handbags, were sure youll succeed with such a classic, iconic and simple replica balenciaga handbags.
